Mandatory extra time is required during busy seasons, including most holidays. Management can be difficult to deal with, people get moved around frequently with new responsibilities assigned often. You feel very insignificant among hundreds of employees each shift, and as many people come and go, it's not obvious that each employee is valued. Rate, volume, and efficiency are considered the highest priority, and this can make work feel overwhelming. Management will be critical about employees meeting their expected rate whatever their job function may be, with penalties enforced on occasion. pros: I really love working for Amazon. The vast majority of people are super friendly and helpful, it's a piece of cake being hired on for good pay, shift differentials are common for various shifts or days, and there are plenty of ways to move up in the company and make a career. They take COVID-19 seriously. They give out free things often--treats, hoodies, reusable COVID masks, shirts, and work shoes via Zappos. Free coffee every shift. The work is physically-intensive but doable, even for a very tiny woman like myself. It's like getting paid to exercise. They go out of their way to recognize and appreciate employees who do the work and do it well. There are more than a handful of ways to request time off if you need it, so you'll never have to work more than you want to (a plus for part-timers or those in school). Despite Amazon being such a huge company, business communication is common and clear and appreciation is often communicated and felt. The most appreciative company I have ever worked for.
cons: Their training leaves a lot to be desired. Half the time people are trained differently than you. People who have been there for months might still not know where something is. I was trained in a critical area a month before being scheduled there because the manager who trained me didn't understand the process of "actually" training me through Learning, thus making my new role official. I applied for a Learning Ambassador position in early February 2021, was accepted as of February 10, but not informed until I personally inquired in early March. The training class for my new role has been rescheduled multiple times. Training is an absolute joke here; if you don't keep on them about it, you will go nowhere. You are a cog in a machine here and you must advocate constantly for yourself or be forgotten.

Your feet will hurt. Badly. You will limp. Seriously. Finding a pair of shoes that you can wear an entire 10.5 hours is tricky. Try changing halfway through?

If you have a good work ethic, you’ll enjoy it, packing is fun—you can challenge yourself, but you’re going to sweat. The better your rate, though, the more they expect you to keep that up constantly, whether you’re ahead of most people or not. And if you’re not at “your” normal, several people will nag you “are you okay” with the dumbest look on their face. They all show up one at a time with that same dumb look. It’s peculiar, and it would be funny if it weren’t annoying.

With no headphones allowed, you have to learn to talk to yourself or sing to yourself or something, otherwise you’ll go nuts. The background noise of the machines is obnoxious, but earplugs aren’t really an option, which isn’t cool. 

Oh! The bathroom! Noooo! Have you had babies in the past? I have. You can only walk in “the green mile” which is a taped off walking lane that will safely guide you in the longest route possible around every possible obstacle between you and the bathrooms...it feels like a 30 minute detour instead of a two-minute straight line. It’s probably 5 or 10 minutes to and from, honestly. Pee quickly because they’re timing you. Literally. You cannot have an emergency pee or #2. That is the unthinkable. Seriously anxiety-provoking thought. I mean, I can’t imagine that ever working out well for anyone. Then, you’d have to walk another 10 minutes or so past a bunch of people to leave. Just no. 

Do you think you’d like driving a little lift truck thingy that puts you four stories up in the air in very narrow aisles where you have to pull stuff off shelves and load it into the wobbly cage attached to your little lift? No? Me, either. Don’t do Pick, Stow, or QA.

People order A LOT of bags of dog food, boxes of water, flats of Gatorade, 40lb bags and boxes of CAT LITTER, printer paper boxes—I mean, just wow. pros:
- Some of the most hardworking, dedicated professionals I've worked with my entire life (consistent among everyone)

- This rigour and work ethic wasn't only evident among engineers, but also present in product managers, designers, teammates from the marketing and business teams I worked with

- The versatility expected of engineers is quite high - which means that if you're on a project with lots of opportunities to work on things you've never worked on before, you can grow quickly

- Strong culture of ownership and never saying "this isn't my job" - everyone takes responsibility for work, fostering a strong sense of collective ownership (at least in the team I've been on), and always follows up on various issues

- Expected to be more than just an engineer - at Amazon, technical excellence is only the cornerstone of your work responsibilities - you're expected to be excellent at project management, communications with stakeholders (internal and external), liaising between different teams, etc. Expect your time to be split 60:40 between coding and non-coding tasks - discussions, research, code reviews, liaising between teams, documentation, communicating with stakeholders, looking over project plans, etc.

- If you're on a good team with an empathetic manager who excels at project management (so you'll rarely get into a situation where there's a lot of last minute rushes), you can strike a good work-life balance - of course, you can also choose to work more if you'd like to accelerate your career progression - the choice is up to you

- Amazing network of helpful senior engineers whose expertise you can rely on - it's not uncommon to ask senior and principal engineers to do design, system, architectural audits for you at a project level, or if you'd like you can always attend office hours / be paired with a senior engineer for mentoring

- There is a very clear path for career progression - there are three most common levels of engineers L4 - L6 (L7 and above are rare). A L4 - L5 promotion generally requires approval from peers, and strong technical skills (although anything on top of that will help), and a L5 - L6 promotion requires approval from those who are outside of engineering disciplines, as well as managers at higher levels. Your manager is incentivized to help you move to the next stage because their performance reviews are based on how well the team they manage do

- A true meritocracy - you are rewarded based on your performance and you can speak up against leaders (respectfully, of course) if you disagree - I've never felt the need to back down just because I was "just an engineer" - if you have a good idea, everyone is willing to listen and act upon it if appropriate
cons:
- No free lunches / inconvenient to find places to eat at pre-COVID, cafeteria offered limited choices

- Only 6 public holidays observed per year

- Compensation heavily skewed towards stock options over base salary (the increase in your base is fairly trivial compared to packages at equivalent levels at Facebook and Google), although the total sum tends to even out

- Sometimes I did feel there was lack of technical leadership - L4 and L5 engineers often had to take up responsibilities typically assigned to L6 engineers (because it's very hard to hire frontend engineers, let alone a senior one) - it was harder on us because we had to gate the quality of the project, think about architectural concerns without lessening the scope of the work we were expected to deliver, which was at times stressful

- Engineers from different teams I spoke all shared one thing in common - "understaffed, and overworked" (the management of the workload can be manageable with a good manager, but it doesn't change the fact that a lot of teams simply don't have funding to hire the engineers to cope with the workload that comes in)

- High turnover - in the one year I was on this team, 9 engineers left - that's around 50% of our team size - vacancies are often hard to fill for frontend roles in particular, which means that there's additional stress imposed on existent members to lead and mentor new engineers on top of project work

- Frontend engineers are a relatively new job title, which means that they're vastly outnumbered by their backend counterparts - it's easy to feel neglected, as well as having a preference to lean towards backend solutions over frontend ones. Oftentimes, there are much less frequent design reviews simply because there are no senior enough engineers to help out with reviews

- Amazon is still very heavily Java focused. Unfortunately, this means that as a frontend engineer, you won't see the strong support and widespread support for Javascript, and indeed, TypeScript, you'd typically see at a smaller dev shop or a consultancy (by support, I mean the sort of expertise I expected to see at a top notch tech company was noticeably absent - there were more TypeScript and JavaScript experts in a small consultancy I used to work in)

- On a similar note, so if you want to explore something with a different tech stack (not just programming languages), you have to fight through hurdles after hurdles to get it approved, not because managers or the team doesn't know those are superior technical solutions, but simply because there's insufficient expertise to properly design architectures and solutions around new tech

- Code quality can be lacking at times - this is not a statement against the technical prowess of engineers, but the fact that Amazon values agility over quality - code bases have a shelf life, and are expected to be rewritten after a period of time. This means that architecturally sustainable engineer practices are often sacrificed for delivery and meeting deadlines

- At times, you'll see the "this is how it's done, so let's stick to it" mentality to prefer the status quo over revolutionary change depending on the project you're working for. I would've expected to see more risk taking, but unfortunately the more conservative approach is preferred because they tend to get approved more easily up the management chain vs. having to justify something that's totally new or never been done before

review_title: Still one of the worst companies in London
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in London, England
pros: You sometimes get to work on interesting projects. The joining bonus is lucrative (that's how they lure you in). The engineers you work with are nice enough (but they're your competitors, so don't be fooled).
cons: Most of the teams in London work on things in other people's codebases. At face value to a candidate, the work sounds interesting, but it definitely isn't. The code bases are full of short term thinking and their attitude to difficult problems is to throw more people at it, rather than try and be efficient - people get promoted for shipping crap, not for sustainable engineering. I have felt my tech skills get worse and worse the longer I've worked there for. In addition you will likely get about 0 base salary increase during your time there. They justify this by stating the shares allocated have gone up, so they don't need to pay you more. In addition to no real rewards after the initial big bonus to lure you (which you will pay for with your sanity), there's also a US-style stack ranking process where your manager is your friend one minute and stabs you in the back the next. Whilst you might think this only happens to the bad ones, I have seen good engineers forced out, so everyone that knows how it works lives in constant fear, those who don't know just aren't aware of the game they're playing and will eventually get caught out. On top of being crap to their engineers, all the stories you read in the papers about firing people for trying to unionise and stand up for their rights is true. The fact they try to cover it up externally just makes it that much more sickening. If you have any self-respect, stay away, it's not worth it just to have the name on your CV. The joining bonus is lucrative, but that's the only redeeming feature.
